value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">25</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">But her passion, her disgrace, her 
            <choice>
              <sic>humiltaion</sic>
              <corr>humiliation</corr>
            </choice> are all acted</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">i in dumb show. They are 
            <choice>
              <sic>hidd n</sic>
              <corr>hidden</corr>
            </choice> either by silence, or by</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">flourishes and ornaments that 
            <choice>
              <sic>amont</sic>
              <corr>amount</corr>
            </choice> to silence.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Even a plain country squire once he takes pen in hand</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">has 
            <choice>
              <sic>recource</sic>
              <corr>recourse</corr>
            </choice> to poetry. <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-fbea" key="Beaumont, Francis">Mr Beaumont</rs>, after trying to ex-</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">plain <quote source="#" rend="inline">"My conceit of this tripple love, of 
            <choice>
              <sic>affcetion</sic>
              <corr>affection</corr>
            </choice> passion</quote></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote source="#" rend="inline">and conjunction"</quote> has recourse to poetry. He quotes <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-espe" key="Spenser, Edmund">Spenser</rs></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">to help him out. It is the poets still who speak for the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">squires. They have no serviceable language Yet behind</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">these florid decorations the wolves of the court prye</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">prey and raven. 
            <choice>
              <sic>astards</sic>
              <corr>Bastards</corr>
            </choice> are born. 
            <choice>
              <sic>eputations</sic>
              <corr>reputations</corr>
            </choice> are 
            <choice>
              <sic>ru ned</sic>
              <corr>ruined</corr>
            </choice>.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Only the auxmxmxmxmxmx people 
            <choice>
              <sic>themslves</sic>
              <corr>themselves</corr>
            </choice> pass unseen.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">They too like the dramatists remain anonymous.</l>

<add xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" place="margin">
            <l>there is an</l> <!-- nope, pray for Dirk's help, try Wim, etc. -->
            <l>[illeg. tiny words...]</l>
            <l/>
            <l/>
            <l/>
            <l/>
            <l/>
            <l/>
            <l/>
            <l/>
            <l/>
            <l/>
          </add>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">And the play itself was still anonymous.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">The lack of <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-cmar" key="Marlowe, Christopher">Marlowes</rs> name, or <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-tkyd" key="Kyd, Thomas">Kyds</rs>, shows how largely</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the play was a common product, written by 
            <choice>
              <sic>o e</sic>
              <corr>one</corr>
            </choice> hand, but so</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">moulded in transition that the author had no 
            <choice>
              <sic>snese</sic>
              <corr>sense</corr>
            </choice> 
            <choice>
              <sic>od</sic>
              <corr>of</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">property in it. It was in part the work of the audience.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">And the audience was a large one. Fifteen hundred</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">people, <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-greg" key="Greg, W. W.">Dr Greg</rs> computes was an average audience,</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Of these the 
            <choice>
              <sic>gr ater</sic>
              <corr>greater</corr>
            </choice> part were apprentices, citizens</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>oredom</sic>
              <corr>boredom</corr>
            </choice> of the afternoon. Their presence is obvious enough</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">in the early plays. It is they who 
            <choice>
              <sic>drw</sic>
              <corr>draw</corr>
            </choice> up the extravagance</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the hyperbole, as a sheet of paper draws 
            <choice>
              <sic>yp</sic>
              <corr>up</corr>
            </choice> the fire.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">It was they who made the playwright capable of his great</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">strides, of vast audacities beyond the reach of the solitary</l>
